title: What will the daily price of the Brazilian real-to-US dollar exchange rate be on 31 October 2017?
preds: Based on general news and GJP consensus.

FOMC meets Oct 31 and Nov 1.  Expect rates not to increase, however, the dollar may strengthen based on language issued by the Fed.  The dollar may also be "talked" up or down based on what the government communicates going forward.
https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomccalendars.htm
http://www.investopedia.com/articles/investing/101215/how-fed-fund-rate-hikes-affect-us-dollar.asp The Brazilian Real may weaken based on what happens in the next two days and on actions taken by the Brazilian Central Bank during the last week.  Their Central Bank also raised rates by 100 basis points in September.

"US Federal Reserve keeps interest rates unchanged and sets October date for balance sheet reduction"
 http://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2017/09/20/pound-advances-nervy-dollar-ahead-key-us-federal-reserve-meeting/ Ok, I'm going against the crowd and risking my Brier Score.  I got burned last time I did this (on the hacking question).  According to Tedlock, this is the value of forecasts by the crowd.  My individual score doesn't matter as much as the recording of a dissenting view (with some rationale for a post-mortem thus an opportunity to learn). What could throw this forecast completely off is who Trump chooses as Yellen's replacement as Fed Reserve Chair and when.  That decision will come sometime this week.  Trump has generally talked down the dollar.  However, there is much opportunity if the dollar surges up then falls.  I'm betting that the announcement comes after Oct. 31.
https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/trump-set-to-name-jerome-powell-as-favourite-to-chair-us-federal-reserve-bdn65hgkj

Just a word of warning to anyone checking the exchange rate in the link provided (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DEXBZUS), it is not updated on a daily basis. The Brazilian Real has depreciated significantly in the past several days and no longer is sitting at 3.1875 as indicated in the link provided. Instead, it is at 3.2899 as of this writing.  I have been wondering why forecasts have been so slow to adjust and came to the conclusion this might be one reason.
Shifting tighter because of passage of time.

3.1730 today, and the price has bounced between 3.11 and 3.19 for the last month. I believe it will remain in this range.
It will not change too much.

The Real has spent most of the past year around 3.10 to 3.20, with dips to 3.30 to 3.50.  I suspect the dollar will run strong versus the real in the short term compared to trend because the euro is going to react to the Catalonia vote (crisis = buy dollars).  So my prediction curve is skewed to a higher rate.
The trends are on www.xe.com, in case anyone would like a reference.

3.1257 and ~ holding steady in most recent data of Sept. 22. As of 1 OCT the Real is .316.  Last October it traded in a range of of .3067 to .3122. Yet, earlier in the year the ongoing political scandal caused a 7% hit to the currency.  If another political hit occurs, it could take the value to 2.95753.  These sudden shocks tend to find near-term recovery.  Hence, the risk is that another scandal hits the value days before the forecast closes.

Based on monthly fluctuations of the real to dollar ratio in past years and the currents events in Brazil I have come to these percentages as a conclusion. Turmoil in Brazil will most likely cause a fall in the value of the currency. Though that may be true past changes show that starting in the moth of September the real value begins to rise. In conclusion based on past changes in the real and current events I have concluded the shown values.
further us political/economic mini-shocks, strong Brazilian economic #s in next 30 days.

Using a low 9% vol (it seems like it should be more but that is what trailing 30, 60 & 90 days says), along with an expected 12 month return of 3%. I am not sure about the expected return/direction of this currency. More of a guess than based on any data.
Update - mark to market; leaning towards stronger BRL
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Key determinant of exchange rate movements during this short timeframe: investor sentiment, which is most likely to be affected by developments on the government's economic reform programme (positive news being likely to strengthen the real).
Progress on pensions reform before end of October now looks unlikely following President Temer's second indictment but it seems this has already been factored into expectations (https://www.ft.com/content/78dfa0e6-98fd-11e7-a652-cde3f882dd7b) with markets optimistic that pensions reform would pick up pace again by the end of the year. 2018 election prospects also relevant to market sentiment but very early days as yet. 
On this basis, feels unlikely that the next 1.5 months will bring sharp movements of the kind seen in May or July this year, and would guess that investors are likely to keep leaning on the optimistic side.

Brazilian Social Democrats new (today) effort to draft Finance Minsiter Meirelles (one of theirs) and his humble denial of being a pre-candidate for president should cause a little firming of greenback in what is still an unstable political-psycholgical situation.
Falling inflation and government help likely to continue

These are approximately the densities of a normal distribution curve with mean 3.106 and standard deviation 0.49, which I have calculated with an ARMA(1,1) model. Basically the same result is obtained when the Real exchange rate is fitted against the US dollar real effective exchange rate, which is the deep determinant (in my view) of the Real exchange rate.
3m forward at 3.12 can be taken as the starting base. Seasonality suggests USDBRL flat to lower by end-October

Am I the only one who has noticed that they have their terminology reversed?  As if today there are 0.32 Brazilian real to the US dollar.  So in fact the answer is 100% less than 2.98.  Is this a trick question?  Also, assuming they mean dollar to real, what if it comes in at 3.21?
Currently at 3.15. Has not been below 3.09 for several years. Was at 3.4 last December. Steady and between 3.1 and 3.4 over last year.
global instability makes for a strong dollar generally.  N korea could drive people to the dollar...
No strong insights.  Distribution based on eyeballing the past 5 years.  If I have time, I'll look more closely at the monthly historic volatility
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
dollar weakness more than real strength

Historical trend, Bloomberg. The political situation has quieted down some, after Pres. Michel Temer stood off an attempt to impeach him in June. Some more news could break in the lava jato scandal that could affect the financial markets, but it seems as if most of it is already known to any actors who might affect the exchange rate. Otherwise, there are likely few short-term market or economic conditions that would affect any significant move.

The Real is moderately volatile, by looking at the time series, and big day-to-day jumps are possible. Forecasts do not seem to think the smoothed trend will change significantly in the next months, but the fluctuations keep this question very open.
FRED right now 3.1463 https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DEXBZUS It would take a black swan to exceed 3.34 or go below 2.98.
I believe that the real will strengthen against the dollar as policy uncertainty and political turmoil continue to disrupt the US economy.

Noticing a consensus bias to the upper bound of 3.22-3.34.  Not agreeing with that.  Level is in a short-term mild downtrend and a longer term solid downtrend.  But I am going to stick with a predominant position on 3.11-3.2 band for the time being, based on short-term time frame and relatively low price volatility during the previous year.   But naturally, the time frame is super short here and F/X trading is a great way to screw yourself, because price action can go any which way for short periods of time.  And we are talking about Brazil, which is a country that has found a way to mess itself up more times with more advantages than virtually anywhere else.  So tomorrow, we could have some damn fool thing cause us to greatly exceed 3.34.  This is not a question to fire and forget to be sure.

Using 12% vol, more or less trailing 60 day vol and expected annual return of 2%. The real question is vol here. Lots of political instability in Brazil, just a question of whether another shoe drops between now and end of October. The real trick to me on this is what to use for volatility. In the past 30 days vol is very low < 10%, but if you go out to 90 days, vol is > 15%.
Expect Brazil to stabilize over the next two months.

Brazil is recovering from the car wash scandal. One of the reforms involves BNDES increasing the interest rate, which should strengthen the real. On the US side, US dollar is weakening, from a combination of DC political instability or Fed Reserve slowness in raising interest rates.   Quantifying all of the above is tough.  Thoughts?

This is my baseline view forecast, before incorporating any views yet. Used normal distribution but may switch to student-t for fatter tails.

Currency moves are usually rather mild compared with other asset classes. At 3.15 on the date of submission, it would take a move of 2% to place it outside the middle bound, and a move of 7% to place it in the extremes in just two months. Most of the Brazilian political drama is dying, which will help stabilize their currency cross-rate.
Simple question to research and update

Using 12% vol, more or less trailing 60 day vol and expected annual return of 3%. The real question is vol here. Lots of political instability in Brazil, just a question of whether another shoe drops between now and end of October.
The U.S. dollar and the real translation of values are not going to do much moving over the next few months. When translated against the Euro I would expect to see more change.
I think the Brazilian economy is slowly improving but is also nearly stagnant. I don't think the currency moves very much in the next couple months but I am also very very slightly optimistic.
Like the Beatles song goes... "I get by with a little help from, uh,  my friends..."

The USD weakening looks to have halted for the time being and some further rebound might be expected. On the other hand, the continuous uncertainty surrounding the Trump administration's capability to enact any kind of significant reform might keep the dollar down for an extended period. The Central Bank of Brazil is in an easing cycle since last October and has lowered its Selic rate by 350 bps this year and could go still lower, although inflation has come down significantly in that time. https://tradingeconomics.com/brazil/interest-rate With both currencies showing weakness, don't expect huge movements over the next months.

Looking at the FRED graph for the Brazilian real here: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DEXBZUS Low since the beginning of the year: May 16, 2017, 3.09. High, May 18, 2017: 3.38. Graph is spiky as heck. This question is a good way to get clobbered but what the heck. As we used to say as kids in ranch country when acting upon a dare, Geronimo!

The peak of inflation in Brazil in the last five years were the months surrounding the impeachment of President Rousseff, with an exchange rate of around 3.9 Brazilian Reals to 1 US dollar.  Since her impeachment, currency deflation began in Brazil and the Real has stabilized just above 3.0.  The country is stable enough to avoid major currency swings in a two month period.
